Comment: I'm pretty sure historically that nintendo tends to gravitate to chipsets and technology that are already easy to mass produce in order to drive down costs.  The Switch had the same CPU as the Nvidia shield.  The Wii had IR lights on the controllers and a sensor bar. A thing that would be easy for them to acquire since it's basically just remote IR lights and tv sensors.  The gamecube cpu was technically custom, but based on a preexisting PowerPC cpu by IBM.  The Game and Watch 2 used a chip already present in calcuators. Also the controllers for the NES are apparently just straight up copied over from the game and watch.  Amiibo are just NFC chips, a thing already used for tracking and for payments.  Switch 2 might be the first time they're not cutting corners by turning an unrelated thing into a video game console. Unless someone can point to an instance of magnetic rails being used for equipment attachment, or the switch 2's hardware being found elsewhere.  Also Nintendo doesn't tend to take losses, so if they're jacking up the price, that's probably how much it cost to make for a profit.
